title: UK GDPR-specific roles
body: What is the role of the Data Protection Officer (DPO)?

_items.text: DPOs monitor compliance, inform and advise on data protection obligations
DPOs are responsible for spotting data breaches
DPOs complete Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) for you

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

DPOs monitor internal compliance, inform and advise on data protection obligations, provide advice regarding Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) and act as a contact point for the organisation both internally and externally.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

DPOs monitor internal compliance, inform and advise on data protection obligations, provide advice regarding Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) and act as a contact point for the organisation both internally and externally.

title: Where does the UK GDPR apply?
displayTitle: Where does the UK GDPR apply?
body:
The UK GDPR applies to the processing of all personal data by organisations based in the UK regardless of whether the processing takes place in the UK or not.

This means that all FCDO staff in the UK and the overseas network must apply the UK GDPR, regardless of the location of post or nationality of the person whose data they are dealing with.

Processing personal data covers the following, irrespective of how the data is collected: collection, recording, organisation, structuring, storage, adaptation or alteration, retrieval, consultation, use, disclosure by transmission, dissemination or otherwise making available, alignment or combination, restriction, erasure or destruction.

Complying with the EU GDPR

There are certain circumstances under which we will still need to apply the EU GDPR to the processing of EEA residents’ personal data. As the UK and EU GDPRs are more or less aligned, this means the processing remains the same. Further guidance will be published on Diplohub and Insight.

title: Introduction to the UK General Data Protection Regulation
body:
This module gives an overview of the UK General Data Protection Regulation (UK GDPR). After completion, you should be able to work more confidently with the requirements of the UK GDPR.

This module explains:

  • What UK GDPR is and why it is needed
  • What personal data the UK GDPR covers
  • Who the UK GDPR applies to and where
  • The lawful bases
  • Individuals’ rights
  • The importance of privacy notices
  • UK GDPR by default  
  • UK GDPR-specific roles
  • Data breaches

title: Test your knowledge of the UK GDPR
displayTitle: Test your knowledge of the UK GDPR
body:
Test your knowledge of the GDPR with the 10 questions below. 

Warning: Do not leave your assessment session as you will not be able to resume your assessment.

_items.text: The GDPR provides standardisation of data protection laws across all European member states, making it easier for organisations to provide services to people in the EU
_items.feedback: The UK GDPR is a regulation that is designed to provide a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency

_items.text: An optional European Directive that organisations are choosing to implement
A way to decrease the amount of spam emails and calls people receive

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The UK GDPR is a regulation that is designed to provide a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency.

Anyone who deals with personal data must be aware of what they can and cannot do with this data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The UK GDPR is a regulation that is designed to provide a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency.

Anyone who deals with personal data must be aware of what they can and cannot do with this data.

title: What is the relationship between the UK GDPR and the EU GDPR?
displayTitle: What is the relationship between the UK GDPR and the EU GDPR?

_items.text: The UK GDPR and EU GDPR are essentially the same
The UK and EU GDPRs are an advisory on how to update regulations
The EU GDPR is a supplementary regulation to the UK GDPR

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

From 1 January 2021, the EU GDPR was retained in UK law. It was renamed the ‘UK GDPR’, to distinguish it from the EU GDPR, but the two GDPRs are essentially the same. The UK GDPR continues to be supplemented in UK law by the Data Protection Act 2018 (DPA 2018).

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

From 1 January 2021, the EU GDPR was retained in UK law. It was renamed the ‘UK GDPR’, to distinguish it from the EU GDPR, but the two GDPRs are essentially the same. The UK GDPR continues to be supplemented in UK law by the Data Protection Act 2018 (DPA 2018).

title: Establishing lawful basis for processing personal data
displayTitle: Establishing lawful basis for processing personal data
body: Which lawful basis is most likely to cover services offered by the FCDO?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Most of what that FCDO does falls under this lawful basis. But we should be careful not to make it our default without considering the other bases first and whether additional ones also apply.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Most of what that FCDO does falls under this lawful basis. But we should be careful not to make it our default without considering the other bases first and whether additional ones also apply.

title: Privacy notices
body: What is wrong with the privacy notice shown here?

_items.text: Confusing title and text in first paragraph
Unclear what the data usage policy is
Not clear who personal information will be shared with

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

This is an example of a particularly bad privacy notice. There is a mix of confusing language, incorrect terminology and misleading information. Additionally the signature box is in the incorrect place. On top of everything outlined here, under the UK GDPR you must allow an electronic request for access to the data, and fulfil this with an electronic copy of the data, unless otherwise requested.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

This is an example of a particularly bad privacy notice. There is a mix of confusing language, incorrect terminology and misleading information. Additionally the signature box is in the incorrect place. On top of everything outlined here, under the UK GDPR you must allow an electronic request for access to the data, and fulfil this with an electronic copy of the data, unless otherwise requested.

title: What do you need to know?
displayTitle: What do you need to know?
body:
This module gives an overview of the UK General Data Protection Regulation. 

After completion, you should able to work more confidently with the requirements of the UK GDPR.

Click here to start learning

title: Introduction
body:
From 1 January 2021, the EU GDPR was retained in UK law. It was renamed the ‘UK GDPR’, to distinguish it from the EU GDPR, but the two GDPRs are essentially the same. The UK GDPR continues to be supplemented in UK law by the Data Protection Act 2018 (DPA 2018).

The UK GDPR is designed to provide accountability and transparency to individuals on the processing of their personal data by organisations.

title: Data breaches
body: If you think you have identified a potential personal data breach, what should you do?

_items.text: Raise it at your next team meeting

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

If you think you have identified a potential personal data breach you should notify the Data Protection Officer who will then decide on the next course of action. 

Breach notification is mandatory where a data breach is likely to result in a risk for the rights and freedoms of individuals. The FCDO must report any such data breaches and those affected, to the ICO within 72 hours of becoming aware of them. We must also keep a record of any personal data breaches, regardless of whether we are required to notify.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

If you think you have identified a potential personal data breach you should notify the Data Protection Officer who will then decide on the next course of action. 

Breach notification is mandatory where a data breach is likely to result in a risk for the rights and freedoms of individuals. The FCDO must report any such data breaches and those affected, to the ICO within 72 hours of becoming aware of them. We must also keep a record of any personal data breaches, regardless of whether we are required to notify.

title: What is personal data?
body: Is a picture of a group of people a piece of personal data?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Under the UK GDPR, ’personal data; means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person. 

This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

Names are not needed to identify someone; you probably don't know the names of all your neighbours but you can identify them in a picture. A digital picture may also offer other information, such as location and timestamp.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Under the UK GDPR, ’personal data; means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person. 

This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

Names are not needed to identify someone; you probably don't know the names of all your neighbours but you can identify them in a picture. A digital picture may also offer other information, such as location and timestamp.

title: Special categories of personal data
body: Which of the following are examples of special categories of personal data?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

‘Special categories of personal data’ (previously referred to as sensitive personal data) merit higher protection as the context of their processing could create significant risks to fundamental rights and freedoms.

These categories include:

  • Racial or ethnic origin
  • Political opinions
  • Religious or philosophical beliefs
  • Trade union membership
  • Genetic and biometric data
  • Physical or mental health or conditions
  • Sex life or sexual orientation

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

‘Special categories of personal data’ (previously referred to as sensitive personal data) merit higher protection as the context of their processing could create significant risks to fundamental rights and freedoms.

These categories include:

  • Racial or ethnic origin
  • Political opinions
  • Religious or philosophical beliefs
  • Trade union membership
  • Genetic and biometric data
  • Physical or mental health or conditions
  • Sex life or sexual orientation

title: Special categories of personal data
body: What do ‘special categories of personal data’ refer to?

_items.text: Data that could create more significant risks to a person's fundamental rights and freedoms
User account passwords and other access keys

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

‘Special categories of personal data’ (previously referred to as sensitive personal data) merit higher protection as the context of their processing could create significant risks to fundamental rights and freedoms.

These categories include:

  • Racial or ethnic origin
  • Political opinions
  • Religious or philosophical beliefs
  • Trade union membership
  • Genetic and biometric data
  • Physical or mental health or conditions
  • Sex life or sexual orientation

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

title: Who does the UK GDPR apply to and where?
displayTitle: Who does the UK GDPR apply to and where?
body: Which individuals does the UK GDPR apply to?

_items.text: All individuals interacting with an organisation operating in the UK regardless of nationality
All UK citizens interacting with any company worldwide

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The UK GDPR will apply to the processing of all personal data by organisations based in the UK, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the UK or not.

The UK GDPR will also apply to the processing of personal data in the UK by an organisation not established in the UK, where the activities relate to either:

  1. Offering goods or services within the UK (irrespective of whether payment is required)
  2. Monitoring of individuals behaviour as far as their behaviour takes place within the UK

This means that even if a company has no physical base in the UK, the UK GDPR may still apply if goods and services are offered to those located within the UK.

On this basis you do not need to be a UK citizen for the UK GDPR to apply. Anyone located in the UK interacting with services offered in the UK is in scope of the UK GDPR.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The UK GDPR will apply to the processing of all personal data by organisations based in the UK, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the UK or not.

The UK GDPR will also apply to the processing of personal data in the UK by an organisation not established in the UK, where the activities relate to either:

  1. Offering goods or services within the UK (irrespective of whether payment is required)
  2. Monitoring of individuals behaviour as far as their behaviour takes place within the UK

This means that even if a company has no physical base in the UK, the UK GDPR may still apply if goods and services are offered to those located within the UK.

On this basis you do not need to be a UK citizen for the UK GDPR to apply. Anyone located in the UK interacting with services offered in the UK is in scope of the UK GDPR.

title: What is personal data?
body: What is the definition of personal data in the UK GDPR?

_items.text: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable person
Any data owned by an individual
Sensitive data, such as health records or salary

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Under the UK GDPR, 'personal data' means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person.

This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

This could be via any identifier, such as a name, email, address, phone number, an identification number, an online identifier (including IP address) or factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that person.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Under the UK GDPR, 'personal data' means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person.

This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

This could be via any identifier, such as a name, email, address, phone number, an identification number, an online identifier (including IP address) or factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that person.

title: What is personal data?
body: Which are the following are examples of personal data covered by the UK GDPR?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Under the UK GDPR, 'personal data' means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person.

This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

This could be via any identifier, such as a name, email, address, phone number, an identification number, an online identifier (including IP address) or factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that person.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Under the UK GDPR, 'personal data' means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person.

This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

This could be via any identifier, such as a name, email, address, phone number, an identification number, an online identifier (including IP address) or factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that person.

title: What personal data does the UK GDPR cover?
displayTitle: What personal data does the UK GDPR cover?
body: There are four different types of personal data that are in scope of the UK GDPR.
instruction: Explore each of these in more detail below.

_items.title: 1. Personal data
_items.body:
Under the UK GDPR personal data means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person. This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

Examples: name, email address, address, phone number, an identification number, an online identifier (including IP address) or factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that person.

However data of these types might not always be personally identifiable. For example the name John Smith is very common, however when combined with other data, such as date of birth and address this then becomes identifiable. Remember that names are not needed to identify someone - you probably don't know the names of all your neighbours but you can identify them.

_items.title: 2. Special categories of personal data
_items.body:
Special categories of personal data (previously referred to as sensitive personal data) merit higher protection as the context of their processing could create significant risks to fundamental rights and freedoms.

These categories include:

  • racial or ethnic origin
  • political opinions
  • religious or philosophical beliefs
  • trade union membership
  • genetic and biometric data
  • physical or mental health or conditions
  • sex life or sexual orientation

_items.title: 3. Criminal convictions data
_items.body:
Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures can only be carried out:

  • under the control of official authority
  • if you can identify a specific condition for processing in Schedule 1 of the DPA 2018

Any comprehensive register of criminal convictions shall be kept only under the control of official authority.

_items.title: 4. Data about children
_items.body: Data about children must be treated carefully as they may be less aware of the risks involved. When consent is required for the use of data about someone under 18 years old, that consent can be given by a holder of parental responsibility for that child or the child if they are deemed competent.

title: Who needs to apply the UK GDPR?
displayTitle: Who needs to apply the UK GDPR?
body:
All FCDO staff must apply the UK GDPR when processing any personal data (eg staff data and that of external customers) - wherever you are based or whatever the nationality of the individual whose data you are processing.

Even if you’re in a department or post that does not process large amounts of personal data, it’s likely that at some point you’ll handle personal data – such as receiving appraisals or compiling a guest list/sending out invitations for an event.

title: How did you do?
body: Complete the assessment to see your result.

_bands.feedback: Could do better! You achieved a score of {{score}}/10.  The lessons would be really valuable to you. Perhaps think about going through the practical lessons before retaking the quiz!

You got half or more right, achieving a score of {{score}}/10.  You have some good knowledge but need to brush up in a few areas. Take a look back at the practical lessons to help fill the gaps in your knowledge.

title: Establishing lawful basis for processing personal data
displayTitle: Establishing lawful basis for processing personal data
body: Which of the following services (that processes personal data) does the FCDO have a legal obligation to provide?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The FCDO is legally obliged to respond to Freedom of Information requests. We record names and contact details of requesters to enable us to communicate with them. We are also required to ask for certain further personal details to verify the identities of those making Subject Access Requests.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The FCDO is legally obliged to respond to Freedom of Information requests. We record names and contact details of requesters to enable us to communicate with them. We are also required to ask for certain further personal details to verify the identities of those making Subject Access Requests.

title: Establishing lawful basis for processing personal data
displayTitle: Establishing lawful basis for processing personal data
body: If the service you are providing to an individual could be provided without collecting personal data then how does the lawful basis apply?

_items.text: You can use a lawful basis to collect personal data anyway
It no longer applies and thus your collection and processing of personal data is unlawful (with the exception of consent)
You can collect the data just in case it becomes useful for any other lawful service

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The UK GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner.

There are six lawful bases outlined in the UK GDPR and at least one must apply; without a lawful basis, it is illegal to collect and process the personal data. 

Additionally, with the exception of consent, if you could reasonably perform your tasks without collecting the personal data then the lawful basis does not apply.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The UK GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner.

There are six lawful bases outlined in the UK GDPR and at least one must apply; without a lawful basis, it is illegal to collect and process the personal data. 

Additionally, with the exception of consent, if you could reasonably perform your tasks without collecting the personal data then the lawful basis does not apply.

title: UK GDPR by default
body: Which of the following are legal requirements under the UK GDPR?

_items.text: Notification of serious breach to a supervisory authority
Hiring a data protection officer by all organisations

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

‘Privacy by design’ is a legal requirement. It requires organisations to consider individuals’ privacy from the start of the design of any system or service rather than being bolted on at the end. 

Under UK GDPR, all organisations have a duty to report any serious data breach to the relevant supervisory authority.

The UK GDPR requires the appointment a data protection officer (DPO) if you are a public authority, or if you carry out certain types of processing activities involving large scales of personal data or special categories of personal data.

The UK GDPR requires personal data to be processed in a manner that ensures its security. It requires that appropriate technical or organisational measures are used.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

‘Privacy by design’ is a legal requirement. It requires organisations to consider individuals’ privacy from the start of the design of any system or service rather than being bolted on at the end. 

Under UK GDPR, all organisations have a duty to report any serious data breach to the relevant supervisory authority.

The UK GDPR requires the appointment a data protection officer (DPO) if you are a public authority, or if you carry out certain types of processing activities involving large scales of personal data or special categories of personal data.

The UK GDPR requires personal data to be processed in a manner that ensures its security. It requires that appropriate technical or organisational measures are used.

title: UK GDPR by default
body: What is a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA)?

_items.text: A compulsory yearly audit of your organisation’s data protection policies
A tool that you can use to identify and reduce the privacy risks of your projects.
A retrospective at the end of a project to analyse whether data protection was adequate

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

A Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) is a tool that you can use to identify and reduce the privacy risks of your projects.

A DPIA helps you to:

  • describe the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing
  • assess necessity, proportionality and compliance measures
  • identify and assess risks to individuals
  • identify any additional measures to mitigate those risks

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

A Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) is a tool that you can use to identify and reduce the privacy risks of your projects.

A DPIA helps you to:

  • describe the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing
  • assess necessity, proportionality and compliance measures
  • identify and assess risks to individuals
  • identify any additional measures to mitigate those risks

title: Data breaches
body: Within what time period of becoming aware of a serious data breach should this be reported to the supervisory authority?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Breach notification is mandatory where a data breach is likely to result in a risk for the rights and freedoms of individuals. You must do this within 72 hours of becoming aware of the breach. You must also inform those affected individuals without undue delay.

You must also keep a record of any personal data breaches, regardless of whether you are required to notify.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Breach notification is mandatory where a data breach is likely to result in a risk for the rights and freedoms of individuals. You must do this within 72 hours of becoming aware of the breach. You must also inform those affected individuals without undue delay.

You must also keep a record of any personal data breaches, regardless of whether you are required to notify.

title: Individual rights
body: The UK GDPR introduces the right to data portability which gives individuals the right to:

_items.text: Request a machine-readable copy of data held about them that they have provided
Transfer data they have provided freely to another organisation
Use their mobile data plan anywhere in the world
Request their data be made available for sale

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The UK GDPR includes a data portability right – the right for an individual to receive personal data they have provided to the controller or that has been gathered automatically by the controller. This must be provided in a commonly used and machine readable format. Additionally the individual has the right to request that the data is transmitted directly to another controller.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The UK GDPR includes a data portability right - the right for an individual to receive personal data they have provided to the controller or that has been gathered automatically by the controller. This must be provided in a commonly used and machine readable format. Additionally the individual has the right to request that the data is transmitted directly to another controller.

title: Individual rights
body: The UK GDPR includes the right to be forgotten which gives individuals the right to:

_items.text: Request that the data controller erase their personal data
Be removed from official and legal documents, such as police records
Be edited out of a TV show where previously consent was given

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The right to be forgotten (or the right to data erasure) entitles the data subject (where conditions permit) to direct the data controller to erase personal data concerning him or her, cease further sharing of the data, and potentially have third parties halt processing of the data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The right to be forgotten (or the right to data erasure) entitles the data subject (where conditions permit) to direct the data controller to erase personal data concerning him or her, cease further sharing of the data, and potentially have third parties halt processing of the data.

title: Individual rights
body: Under the UK GDPR, in certain circumstances, individuals have the right to request a copy of data they have provided. How should this be provided?

_items.text: In a commonly used machine readable format

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The UK GDPR gives rights of access to individuals to find out from the data controller whether or not personal data concerning them is being processed, and if it is, to access it as well as information about how the data is being collected, used and shared. 

While rights to access are present under the Data Protection Act (DPA), the UK GDPR specifies that the right to request and access personal data should be free of charge.

The UK GDPR also states that if the individual makes the request electronically, the information should be provided electronically, unless otherwise requested.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The UK GDPR gives rights of access to individuals to find out from the data controller whether or not personal data concerning them is being processed, and if it is, to access it as well as information about how the data is being collected, used and shared. 

While rights to access are present under the Data Protection Act (DPA), the UK GDPR specifies that the right to request and access personal data should be free of charge.

The UK GDPR also states that if the individual makes the request electronically, the information should be provided electronically, unless otherwise requested.

title: Individual rights
body: Under the UK GDPR, in certain circumstances, individuals have the right to request a copy of data they have provided. How much can be changed for this service?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The UK GDPR give rights of access to individuals to find out from the data controller whether or not personal data concerning them is being processed, and if it is, to access it as well as information about how the data is being collected, used and shared. 

While rights to access are present under the Data Protection Act (DPA), the UK GDPR specifies that the right to request and access personal data should be free of charge.

The UK GDPR also states that if the individual makes the request electronically, the information should be provided electronically, unless otherwise requested.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The UK GDPR give rights of access to individuals to find out from the data controller whether or not personal data concerning them is being processed, and if it is, to access it as well as information about how the data is being collected, used and shared. 

While rights to access are present under the Data Protection Act (DPA), the UK GDPR specifies that the right to request and access personal data should be free of charge.

The UK GDPR also states that if the individual makes the request electronically, the information should be provided electronically, unless otherwise requested.

title: Privacy notices

_items.text: Not clear what a subject access request is
There cannot be a charge for the right to access
The signature box comes before the terms are complete

On top of everything outlined here, under the UK GDPR you must allow an electronic request for access to the data, and fulfil this with an electronic copy of the data, unless otherwise requested.

Additionally the signature box is in the incorrect place. On top of everything outlined here, under the UK GDPR you must allow an electronic request for access to the data, and fulfil this with an electronic copy of the data, unless otherwise requested.

title: Privacy notices
body: What is wrong with the privacy notice shown here?

_items.text: Not clear who personal information will be shared with
Marketing should be opt-in, not out
A link to this training should be included

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

This is an example of a particularly bad privacy notice. There is a mix of confusing language, incorrect terminology and misleading information. Additionally the signature box is in the incorrect place. On top of everything outlined here, under the UK GDPR you must allow an electronic request for access to the data, and fulfil this with an electronic copy of the data, unless otherwise requested.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

This is an example of a particularly bad privacy notice. There is a mix of confusing language, incorrect terminology and misleading information. Additionally the signature box is in the incorrect place. On top of everything outlined here, under the UK GDPR you must allow an electronic request for access to the data, and fulfil this with an electronic copy of the data, unless otherwise requested.

title: Individual rights
body: Which of the following rights are introduced or enhanced for individuals in the UK GDPR?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

One of main changes introduced by the UK GDPR is the addition and enhancement of a number of individual rights including the right to access, right to erasure and right to portability.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

One of main changes to UK GDPR Is the addition and enhancement of a number of individuals rights including the right to access, right to erasure and right to portability.

title: What is the UK GDPR and why is it needed?
displayTitle: What is the UK GDPR and why is it needed?
body: The world we live in today is vastly different from when the 1998 Data Protection Act was law. The UK GDPR provides a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency.

title: Establishing the lawful basis for processing personal data
body:
The UK GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner. There are six lawful bases outlined in the UK GDPR. At least one must apply. Without a lawful basis, it is illegal to collect and process personal data. 

Additionally, with the exception of the Consent lawful basis, if you could reasonably perform your tasks without collecting personal data then the lawful basis does not apply. If you could provide the same service without collecting personal data, but still want to collect that data, you have to get consent from the individual.

_items.title: Public task
_items.body:
You can process personal data if it is necessary for you to perform a task in the public interest or for your official functions, where the task or function has a clear basis in law.

Most of what that FCDO does falls under this lawful basis. But we should be careful not to make it our default without considering the other bases first and whether additional ones also apply.

FCDO examples:

Conferences and events

Personal data on those attending including name, address, dietary requirements

Consular Assistance

Personal data on those receiving assistance, including name, date of birth, address, passport number, next of kin, nature of case and record of assistance provided (which may also include information from third parties such as police).

Prism and Vault

Stores personnel data of FCDO staff and secondees: HR data, Payroll data, Contract data, Customer financial data.

_items.title: Performance of contract
_items.body:
You can process personal data if you need to fulfil a contract you have with the individual, or if they have asked you to take specific steps before entering into a contract.

There are few, if any acts of processing in the FCDO that would result in this lawful basis being preferred over public task, including for any commercial contracts.

_items.title: Legal obligation
_items.body:
You can process personal data if you need to in order to comply with UK law. For example, if the FCDO needs to process personal data to comply with UK employment law. Contractual obligations you have with third parties do not count as a lwaful basis for processing. 

If you are processing personal data on the basis of a legal obligation, the individual has no right to data portability, or right to object (see Individuals’ rights section further on). An individual has a right to erasure if the legal obligation has expired. For example, if someone left a company over 3 years ago then there is unlikely to be a legal obligation for the employer to keep hold of data about that person (a very small quantity is required for longer). 

FCDO examples:

Income information for tax purposes

The FCDO is required to pass information to HMRC about the taxable income we have paid to staff and deductions we have made for tax and national insurance. We are also required to provide other data such as your home address to assist HMRC’s work.

Retention of certain staff records

Under the rules of the Principal Civil Service Pension Scheme we are required to keep records of service history and pensionable salary and allowances until the employee concerned is 100 or until death in case of any queries about their pension entitlements.  

Freedom of Information requests

The FCDO is legally obliged to respond to Freedom of Information requests. We record names and contact details of requesters to enable us to communicate with them. We are also required to ask for certain further personal details to verify the identities of those making Subject Access Requests.

_items.title: Vital interests
_items.body:
You can process personal data if it is necessary to protect someone’s life. This does not apply if you can reasonably protect the person’s vital interests in another less intrusive way.

This lawful basis also does not apply for health data or other special category data if the individual is capable of giving consent.

FCDO example:

Consular crisis response
Collection and use of personal data when we need to evacuate people quickly, such as natural disasters/emergencies, outbreak of an epidemic/pandemic etc.

_items.title: Legitimate interests
_items.body:
You can process personal data if doing so is in the legitimate interests of the individual, third parties, or society. Legitimate interests is the most flexible lawful basis for processing, but you cannot assume it will always be the most appropriate. 

There are few, if any acts of processing in the FCDO that would result in this lawful basis being preferred over public task.

_items.title: Consent
_items.body:
Individuals must be informed about how personal data is going to be used and consent given for each use. You cannot ask for open-ended consent to use data however you want to. 

Gaining consent must be through clear affirmative action, such as a button press or an opt-in tick box. Hidden conditions and opt-out options where no action is required does not constitute clearly obtained consent under UK GDPR.

Additionally the individual must be able to withdraw their consent at any time. The process for withdrawing consent must be as easy to complete as that for giving consent.

In general, the consent lawful basis can be difficult to get right. If you think you need to use this lawful basis, contact the data.protection@fcdo.gov.uk mailbox for advice.

FCDO example:

The Consular Customer Insight Team use data collected by various methods, to be passed to their partner research agency (IFF Research) for purposes of contacting the customer for feedback. Where data has been collected by online methods (Emergency Travel Documents, Legalisation and CABS) this data is retained as a result of active consent.

_items.title: Data Protection Officer
_items.body:
The UK GDPR requires public authorities to appoint a Data Protection Officer (DPO).  The FCDO’s DPO operates independently of our internal hierarchy and reports to the PUS. 

DPOs monitor internal compliance, inform and advise on data protection obligations, provide advice regarding Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) and act as a contact point for the organisation both internally and externally.

_items.title: Data Controller
_items.body: Data controller means a person who (either alone or jointly or in common with other persons) determines the purposes for which and the manner in which any personal data are, or are to be processed.

_items.title: Data Processor
_items.body: Data processor, in relation to personal data, means any person (other than an employee of the data controller) who processes the data on behalf of the data controller.

title: Data subject rights
body: Data subjects have a number of rights under UK GDPR. These rights are particularly relevant if the lawful basis for processing personal data is either through consent or contract lawful bases. However, they are not all automatic under the public task lawful basis.

_items.title: Right to be informed
_items.body:
Individuals have the right to be informed about how personal data about them is collected and used. This is a key transparency requirement under the UK GDPR.

This information should be presented in a privacy notice (see section further on). This should be presented to the individual when data is collected, in clear, concise language and be easily accessible.

_items.title: Right to access (Subject Access Requests [SARs])
_items.body:
The UK GDPR gives people the right to ask the FCDO whether or not personal data about them is being processed, in what territory and for what purpose.

This right to access exists in the Data Protection Act 2018 (DPA) and the FCDO does not charge for this. Under the UK GDPR, the FCDO must provide a copy of the personal data within a month of the request and in an electronic format where possible.

_items.title: Right to rectification
_items.body: Individuals have the right to have personal data corrected if it is inaccurate or incomplete. Where necessary, the FCDO must also correct any copies shared with others.

_items.title: Right to be forgotten
_items.body:
The right to be forgotten (or the right to data erasure) entitles an individual to direct the controller to erase personal data about them, cease further sharing of the data, and potentially  halt processing of the data by third parties.

Data must be erased if:

  • it is no longer relevant to the original purpose for processing
  • no lawful basis exists for the data to be held and processed
  • an individual withdraws consent

This right does NOT apply to individuals whose data has been processed to carry out government functions (public task).

_items.title: Right to restrict processing
_items.body:
Individuals have a right to ‘block’ or suppress processing of personal data.

Such rights can be exercised when:

  • the accuracy of the personal data is contested
  • where the individual has objected to the processing (only in the case of performance of a public task or legitimate interest)
  • the processing is unlawful
  • the data is needed for future reference but should no longer be processed

_items.title: Right to data portability
_items.body:
The right for an individual to receive personal data they have provided to the FCDO or that has been gathered automatically by us. This must be provided in a commonly-used and machine readable format. Additionally the individual has the right to request that the data is transmitted directly to another organisation.

The "improving data quality" module (available in GLO as part of the FCDO data skills course) contains further information on providing data in the correct format.

_items.title: Right to withdraw consent (if applicable)
_items.body:
If the lawful basis for processing is based on having the consent lawful basis, the individual has the right to withdraw that consent at any time. 

The process of withdrawing consent must be as easy as giving consent in the first place.

_items.title: Right to object
_items.body:
Individuals have the right to object to the FCDO processing data about them. The right to object is not an absolute right and it applies only in certain circumstances. If one of these circumstances is met, you must stop processing data about them. The valid circumstances are:

  • when personal data is used for direct marketing (in this case the right is absolute as a data subject can object at any time)
  • when data is used for research or statistical purposes, unless the processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest (e.g. in health research)
  • the data is processed based on public or legitimate interests

If you wish to continue processing you will need to demonstrate you have compelling legitimate interest that overrides the individual’s rights and freedoms.

_items.title: Right not be subjected solely to automated decision making
_items.body:
Individuals have the right not to be subjected to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling.

Automated processing can be carried out if the decision is:

  • necessary for the entry into or performance of a contract
  • authorised in law
  • based on the individual’s explicit consent

In all cases individuals must be informed about the automated processing and be able to request human intervention or challenge a decision.

title: Privacy Notices
body:
The UK GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully and communicate this basis clearly with the individual. Privacy notices are one of the most visible aspects that demonstrate compliance with the UK GDPR. The FCDO’s Privacy Notices are on our .gov.uk pages. The footer which appears on the bottom of all our external emails directs recipients to this page. The staff Privacy Notice is here.

Individuals must be informed clearly about what data is collected, exactly what it is used for and how they can exercise their rights over the data. This information must be presented to the individual as near to the point of data collection as possible. 

In addition to fines being imposed for non-compliance, they can also be imposed where a privacy notice is deemed unclear or misleading.

title: How well do you know the UK GDPR?
displayTitle: How well do you know the UK GDPR?
body: Take the quiz and test your knowledge

title: More information
body: For more internal guidance see here. Contact data.protection@fcdo.gov.uk with any queries. The Information Commissioner's Office also has a lot of useful information.

title: Data breaches
body:
The UK GDPR imposes a duty on all organisations to report any serious data breach to the Information Commissioner’s Office. A personal data breach means a breach of security leading to the unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data. This includes both accidental and deliberate breaches.

Breach notification is mandatory where a data breach is likely to result in a risk for the rights and freedoms of individuals. The FCDO must report any such data breaches and those affected, to the Information Commissioner’s Office within 72 hours of becoming aware of them. We must also keep a record of any personal data breaches, regardless of whether we are required to notify.

Significant penalties can be imposed on organisations who breach the UK GDPR.

_items.title: Privacy by design
_items.body:
'Privacy by design' is a legal requirement. It requires organisations to consider people’s privacy from the start of the design of any system or service and not just bolt it on at the end.

Where data processing is likely to result in a high risk to individuals, a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) is required under the UK GDPR.

A DPIA helps you to:

  • describe the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing
  • assess necessity, proportionality and compliance measures
  • identify and assess risks to individuals
  • identify any additional measures to mitigate those risks

_items.title: Contracts with data processors
_items.body:
Where the FCDO has a contract with an external supplier, the FCDO will usually be the data controller and the supplier will be the data processor (see UK GDPR-specific role section). This relationship will be set out in the contract. The FCDO must only contract with suppliers who can provide sufficient guarantees that the requirements of the UK GDPR will be met and individuals’ rights protected.

Suppliers can only process personal data on the documented instructions of the FCDO. Suppliers, however, have some direct responsibilities under the UK GDPR, such as having to give notification of data breaches, and being subject to fines or other sanctions if they do not comply.

_items.title: Records of processing
_items.body:
The UK GDPR contains explicit provisions requiring you to document your processing activities (what you do with personal data). 

As well as being a legal requirement, documenting your processing activities can support good data governance and help you demonstrate your compliance with other aspects of the UK GDPR.

The amount of documentation required depends on the size of your organisation and the activities it carries out.

Documentation can help in many areas including:

  • establishing the extent of personal data your organisation holds
  • establishing the lawful basis for processing personal data
  • writing clearer privacy statements
  • fulfilling your obligations to share the data with others including those the data is about
  • records keeping including which territory data is stored in, records of consent and Data Protection Impact Assessment reports
  • responding to queries from your supervisory authority (eg ICO)
  • notification and management of data breaches

_items.title: Ensuring transfers are legitimate
_items.body:
The UK GDPR allows for the free flow of personal data from the UK to the EU/EEA, Gibraltar and other Adequate countries. On 26 June 2021 the EU granted the UK Adequacy which also allows for the free flow of personal data from these jurisdictions. 

Transfers outside of the EEA may be made:

  • to countries that the UK has agreed provide an adequate level of protection (Adequate countries)
  • to organisations where appropriate protection is provided through contractual clauses
  • with the individual's informed consent
  • where it is absolutely necessary to fulfil the lawful basis

_items.title: Data retention and security
_items.body:
The UK GDPR requires personal data to be processed securely. This includes protection against unauthorised or unlawful processing and against accidental loss, destruction or damage. It requires that appropriate technical or organisational measures are used.

Additionally, the UK GDPR requires that personal data only be retained while there is a lawful basis for doing so, such as needing to have proof of a contract or employment. It might not be necessary to keep the complete record for this, rather only a part. This is a practice known as data minimisation that can also help minimise risk.

_items.title: Data minimisation
_items.body: The practice of data minimisation is about limiting personal data collection, storage, usage and retention to only the data that is relevant and absolutely necessary for carrying out the purpose for which the data is processed.

title: Privacy Notices - a checklist
body:
The Privacy Notice should clearly outline:

  • the purpose and lawful basis of the processing
  • the name of the controller and contact details of the data protection officer
  • details of data transfers to third countries and safeguards
  • the retention period or criteria used to determine the retention period
  • the individual’s rights
  • the existence of automated decision making, including profiling and information about how decisions are made, their significance and their consequences

title: Where does the UK GDPR apply?
displayTitle: Where does the UK GDPR apply?
body:
The UK GDPR applies to the processing of all personal data by organisations based in the UK. Our overseas network is part of the FCDO’s single legal entity so staff in all our missions must comply with the UK GDPR.

Data flows to/from the EU/EEA

The UK GDPR allows for the free flow of personal data from the UK to the EU/EEA. In June 2021 the EU granted the UK Adequacy which also allows for the free flow of personal data from the EU/EEA to the UK.

title: What this means for personal data processing
displayTitle: What this means for personal data processing
body:
This means you should continue to process personal data in compliance with the UK GDPR. There may be other changes that you will need to take account of and we will update this guidance as soon as we have the detail from DCMS.

The Information Commissioner remains the UK’s independent supervisory authority on data protection.

title: International transfers
body: Which countries can an individual’s personal data be transferred to without the use of appropriate mechanisms?

_items.text: Any EU country or third country approved by the UK as being Adequate

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The EU and UK consider each other adequate for the transfer of personal data. This means personal data can flow between the 2 parties and, separately, any Adequate countries.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The EU and UK consider each other adequate for the transfer of personal data. This means personal data can flow between the 2 parties and, separately, any Adequate countries.
